references: To combine these advantages, a hierarchical FL system is considered, which has one cloud server, sğ‘ s edge servers indexed by â„“â„“\ell, with disjoint client sets {ğ’â„“}â„“=1ssuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ’â„“â„“1ğ‘ \{\mathcal{C}^{\ell}\}_{\ell=1}^{s}, and nğ‘›n clients indexed by iğ‘–i and â„“â„“\ell, with distributed datasets {ğ’Ÿiâ„“}i=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–â„“ğ‘–1ğ‘\{\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\ell}\}_{i=1}^{N}. Other key notations that are important for the algorithm and the theoretical analysis are summarized in Table I. The hierarchical FL system exploits the natural client-edge-cloud communication hierarchy in current communication networks.

. Next, by applying the theoretical analysis to a system design problem, i.e., the aggregation interval selection problem, we will illustrate how the analytical result can be used to reduce the overall training latency in hierarchical federated learning.
